content.user_title: Analyze single-cell omics data with scvi-tools
content.value_statement: Single-cell genomics analysis requires specialized probabilistic models for dimensionality reduction, batch correction, and integration across diverse modalities. scvi-tools provides deep generative models built on PyTorch for comprehensive single-cell data analysis.
actual_capabilities: Perform unsupervised dimensionality reduction and batch correction using scVI model
Conduct semi-supervised cell type annotation with scANVI and transfer learning
Integrate multimodal data including CITE-seq, ATAC-seq, and spatial transcriptomics
Execute differential expression analysis with uncertainty quantification
Train deep generative models on single-cell count data
Apply spatial deconvolution to map cell types to spatial locations
limitations: Requires raw count data in AnnData format - normalized data not suitable
GPU recommended for large datasets but works on CPU with reduced performance
Models require sufficient cell counts per group for stable estimates
Limited to Python environment with scvi-tools and scanpy dependencies

use_cases.title: Multi-batch scRNA-seq integration

use_cases.title: Cell type annotation transfer
use_cases.description: Transfer cell type labels from annotated reference datasets to new query datasets using semi-supervised learning with uncertainty estimates.

use_cases.title: Spatial deconvolution analysis

prompt_templates.title: Basic scVI workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up and train an scVI model on my single-cell RNA-seq data for dimensionality reduction and batch correction. Use raw counts, register batch covariates, and extract latent representations for downstream clustering.

prompt_templates.title: Cell type annotation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use scANVI to annotate my single-cell dataset. Some cells already have labels in the 'cell_type' column. Train a semi-supervised model to predict labels for unlabeled cells and return prediction probabilities.

prompt_templates.title: Differential expression
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform differential expression analysis between two cell populations using my trained scVI model. Use Bayesian hypothesis testing with change mode, delta=0.25 threshold, and return genes with their log fold changes and Bayes factors.

prompt_templates.title: Reference mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply scArches to map my query dataset to a pretrained scVI reference model. Fine-tune the model, extract query embeddings, and transfer cell type annotations using KNN classification.

output_examples.input: Train scVI on my scRNA-seq data with batch correction
output:
- Setup: Register AnnData with batch_key='sample' and layer='counts'
- Train: 400 epochs with early stopping
- Extract: Get latent representation stored in adata.obsm['X_scVI']
- Output: Batch-corrected embeddings ready for clustering and UMAP visualization

best_practices: Always use raw (unnormalized) count data for scvi-tools models
Filter low-quality cells and genes before training to improve model performance
Register all known technical covariates (batch, donor, percent_mito) in setup_anndata
Save trained models to avoid retraining on the same data
anti_patterns: Using log-normalized data instead of raw counts for model input
Training without specifying batch_key when integrating multiple samples
Applying scVI embeddings directly without validation of batch correction
Ignoring model training metrics and convergence indicators

faq.question: What data formats does scvi-tools support?
faq.answer: scvi-tools works with AnnData objects containing raw count matrices. Supports 10x matrices, loom files, and h5ad format through scanpy.

faq.question: How much RAM do I need for scvi-tools?
faq.answer: Memory usage scales with cells and genes. Start with 16GB RAM for small datasets under 50k cells. Large datasets may require 64GB+.

faq.question: Can scvi-tools integrate with Seurat or Scanpy?
faq.answer: Yes, scvi-tools outputs store results in AnnData objects compatible with scanpy. Use scanpy for clustering, visualization, and downstream analysis.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using scvi-tools?
faq.answer: scvi-tools processes data locally in your Python environment. No data leaves your machine. Models train offline without external network calls.

faq.question: Why is my model not converging?
faq.answer: Check that input data contains raw counts (not normalized). Verify no NaN values exist. Reduce learning rate or increase training epochs if needed.

faq.question: How does scvi-tools compare to Seurat integration?
faq.choice: scvi-tools provides probabilistic modeling with uncertainty quantification while Seurat uses anchor-based alignment methods.
